history.content:
While it's technically possible, it's very difficult.  I've had students successfully complete them, and even perform well in both, but I've never had a student do so and say that they enjoyed it or that they weren't extremely stressed for the majority of the ten weeks.  There are some other variables that would affect my answer, such as, do you tend to be able to "power-through" new, abstract math concepts so long as you have enough time to study?  Or do you prefer to do initial studying then let things ruminate for awhile before actually being able to tackle things like a new proof?  The latter would make things even more difficult.  Feel free to contact me if you'd like to talk offline about your personal experience and what your motivations are for taking them this summer.  Hope this helps!

TL;DR Definitely not recommended for the average student. Worse than 61A/54 in the summer but perhaps not quite as bad as 61B/C in the summer.

children.subject: what doesn't kill you makes you stronger

history.content:
How difficult would it be to take both CS61BL and CS70 over the summer? I've heard that CS70 is not as hard as during a regular semester but we would also be learning material at double the speed. 

Any opinions or advice?
history.subject: CS61BL and CS70 Summer
